column1: organisation_name
column3: Healthcare professionals use digital systems to get a complete view of patients existing medications/prescriptions
column4: What proportion of inpatient medications are prescribed digitally in your organisation?
column5: What proportion of discharge medications are prescribed digitally in your organisation?
column6: What proportion of outpatient medications are prescribed digitally in your organisation?
column7: What proportion of chemotherapy is prescribed digitally in your organisation?
column8: Digital prescribing is routinely performed across all specialties, departments and sites.
column9: Complex medicines and infusions are routinely prescribed digitally
column10: When prescribing, healthcare professionals have access to department, specialty or organisation level medication order sets.
column11: Reference sources are seamlessly available during the digital prescribing process
column12: When prescribing, healthcare professionals are alerted of drug: drug interactions, allergy intolerance, duplication of therapeutic class of drug, out of range doses.
column13: Calculation of medication doses, based on height, weight or body surface area, is enabled digitally.
column14: Completion of a patient risk assessment form offers best practice guidance and prompts prescription of appropriate medications
column15: Medicines and infusions are automatically scheduled for administration and the outcome is digitally recorded, including reasons for non-administration.
column16: Your organisation digitally monitors prescribed medications administered early, late or not administered at all, and reviews the reasons recorded.
column17: What proportion of patients and medicines are positively identified prior to administration through automatic identification and data capture using barcode technology?
column18: Monitoring of patients on high risk medications is enabled digitally; healthcare professionals are prompted to monitor relevant laboratory tests (such as INR or drug concentration) results are tracked and there is documentation of actions taken.
column19: Your organisation digitally monitors all adverse events resulting from medicines administration and has an audit trail to show actions taken and follow up, including yellow card reporting to MHRA.
column20: Antibiotics are routinely prescribed digitally based on local or national formulary guidelines for the clinical indication documented, with prompts to consider IV to oral switching after a pre-defined course length.
